data.title: The Church Discography
data.text:

Brief review in Billboard, Feb. 14, 1987:

Aussie outfit debuts here with a drum-heavy set of technopop. First single, "So Much For Love," was a hit Down Under and is already finding favor on U.S. dance floors. Lack of depth casts doubts on the group's prospects for long-term success, however.

Notes

On the Parole Records/Festival CD release, the front booklet was placed in an outer sleeve with a more legible album title (see photo above). The CD trayliner contains this photo of the band members:

Brief review in Billboard, April 23, 1988:

Oz quartet is much, much improved from its rather lackluster U.S. debut; shift away from Thompson Twins sound toward INXS brings a needed beefy texture to outfit's wayward melodies. Fine "Bitter Tears" is first single, but nifty "Little Change" could rake 'em in at album rock outlets.

THE NINE O'CLOCK MUSE (1984)

Releases

CASS - Australian Broadcasting Corp. C 38213 (Australia)

Notes

The song "Girls Cry Boys Talk" is an early version of "Nothing Changes" off their debut album Step Off The Edge, with different words and a slightly different arrangement. This album was collated from material recorded for the Nine O'Clock Muse radio series on 2JJJ FM (featuring Stuart Matchett), broadcast between August and November, 1983.

2CD - Festival Records 334552 (Australia) - June 3, 2002 - Digipak

Notes

Booklet contains this brief write-up on Venetians:

For all the consistency of the talent flow from affiliated independents, Festival was still actively developing talent in-house. Ininity was still active, carrying acts such as Western Flyer in the late seventies, and was joined in the early eighties by the Parole imprint (established, it is said, so that release sheets, posters and ads could be emblazoned with the heading 'Out On Parole'). Perth group Boys had three charting singles and two charting albums on the fairly short-lived label but its biggest act was the slick synth-pop Venetians, led by Englishman Rik Swinn, who managed nine charting singles between 1983 and 1988, including the top ten So Much For Love.
